lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
In JSX, how do you reference a variable defined in JavaScript inside a JSX tag?

Using curly braces { }Using square brackets [ ]Using parentheses ( )Using angle brackets < >

Using curly braces { }.

lessons.title: Lesson #4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a JSX element that uses an embedded expression to show the result of a calculation: 5 + 3.

Make sure to pick result followed by { and then result, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Pass the name property to the Quote component and render it.

Make sure to pick name followed by props and then ., name.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
In JSX, what will the website display when the JSX {10 * 2} is rendered?

2010 * 2{10 * 2}102

Make sure to pick 20.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Pass the number 42 as the property mysteriousNumber to the NumberMystery component.

Make sure to pick mysteriousNumber followed by = and then {, 42, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a button that logs the text "Hello World!" to the console when clicked.

Make sure to pick onClick followed by = and then {, sayHello, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the React component to track and display the number of bagel orders.

Make sure to pick useState followed by bagels and then setBagels, useState, setBagels, bagels.

lessons.title: Lesson #4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of these is an example of a state variable declaration using useState?

const [count, setCount] = useState(0);const count = useState(0);useState(0);const [count] = 0;

const [count, setCount] = useState(0);.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Call the setter function to update the state variable on button click.

Make sure to type setName.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the correct syntax to add a click event handler to a button in React?

onClick={handleFunction}onclick("handleFunction")click={()=>handleFunction}OnClick=handleFunction()

Make sure to pick onClick={handleFunction}.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a React component that displays your favorite book's title and author.

Make sure to type {title}.

lessons.title: Lesson #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
In JSX, why is it necessary to use a closing slash for self-closing tags that don't require it in plain HTML?

JSX syntax rules require itTo differentiate it from HTMLTo ensure backward compatibilityTo make the code more readable

JSX syntax rules require it.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is returned when the following JSX code is rendered?

73 + 4h1[[object Object]]

Make sure to pick 7.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Render the passed props to make the page work as expected.

Make sure to pick props followed by props and then .name, props, .year, props, .director.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Attach the right event handler to make sure clicks are registered.

Make sure to type onClick.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following correctly uses multiple props to pass values?

<Character name="Mickey" costume="Sorcerer" /><Character name-"Mickey" costume-"Sorcerer" /><Character[name="Mickey"][costume="Sorcerer"]/>Character("name": "Mickey", "costume": "Sorcerer")

<Character name="Mickey" costume="Sorcerer" />.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the initial value of count in the following code?

501undefined

Make sure to pick 5.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use the useState hook to toggle a light switch and initiate the state variable with the value false.

Make sure to type useState(false).

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why doesn't updating a regular variable in React rerender the page?

React doesn't track the changes of regular variablesRegular variables automatically update the DOMRegular variables are only used for storing elementsReact only updates numbers, not strings

React doesn't track the changes of regular variables.

lessons.title: Lesson #4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Read the following code block. What will this log to the console when the button is clicked?

100, as the state change doesn't happen immediately110, as the state changes immediatelyNothing, as we don't log anything120, as the state updates twice on button click

100, as the state change doesn't happen immediately.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following is NOT a valid self-closing tag in JSX?

<p /><br /><img /><MyComponent />

<p />.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Write a React component to display the total of two given numbers using an embedded expression.

Make sure to pick { followed by number1 and then +, number2, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
Write a React component that uses a JSX expression inside a paragraph to display a user's full name, starting with the first name.

Make sure to pick { followed by firstName and then }, {, lastName, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which property type cannot be directly rendered in React without conversion?

BooleanStringNumberObject

Make sure to pick Boolean.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Pass the string "pizza" as the value of the property likes.

Make sure to pick likes, followed by =, and finally "pizza".

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Let's log the props of a component that displays a message from a superhero.

Make sure to pick props followed by console and then ., log, props.

lessons.title: Lesson #4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of these functions will correctly log "You clicked me!" when a button is clicked?

const showMessage = () => console.log("You clicked me!");function showMessage() {return "You clicked me!";}const showMessage = () => {return "You clicked me!";}const showMessage = function() {alert("You clicked me!");}

const showMessage = () => console.log("You clicked me!");.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Implement the state variable counter for coffee orders.

Make sure to pick const followed by [ and then coffees, ,, setCoffees, ], =, useState, (, 0, ), ;.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Display the state variable mood inside an embedded expression.

Make sure to type {mood}.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the primary purpose of the useState hook in React?

To manage state in componentsTo create componentsTo render components on the serverTo apply CSS styles to components

To manage state in components.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Call setVotes inline and wrap it in an arrow function to ensure it gets called with the button click.

Make sure to pick ( followed by ) and then =>, setVotes(votes + 1).

lessons.title: Example: setState()
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the code to update the character and the clothes correctly.

Make sure to pick character followed by setClothes and then setCharacter, setClothes.
